awd_titl_txt: Computational and developmental investigations of children’s self-representations and learning decisions
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE) Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Drs. Julian Jara-Ettinger and Julia Leonard at Yale University, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist studying the development of children’s self-representations. Children’s understanding of the self––what they like, what they know, what they are good at––has a deep influence on their learning and achievement. However, we lack a clear understanding of how exactly children develop views of the self, how these views are affected by their social interactions, and how they impact important real-world behaviors, such as children’s learning decisions. This research will advance fundamental scientific knowledge on children’s self-representations by developing a formal, quantitative theory of how children revise self-representations in social contexts, and how these self-representations impact their learning.

The studies will combine computational and developmental approaches to test the hypothesis that children rationally construct and revise self-representations by integrating their prior experiences with social interactions. First, we will build a computational model that combines self-observations (e.g., failures and successes) with social feedback (e.g., what others think of the self) to explain learning about the self in social contexts. This model will be exhaustively tested and refined through studies with adults and compared against published developmental findings on relevant work. Second, we will use our model and alternative lesioned models to generate and test quantitative predictions for the developmental trajectory of children’s (3- to 6-year-olds) reasoning about the self. These models will make different assumptions about children’s sensitivities to self-observations and social feedback and if and how they integrate these sources of information. Our developmental experiment will systematically vary children’s performance on toys and a teacher’s beliefs about their competence, and test how these inform important learning behaviors: children’s persistence and challenge-seeking. By integrating state-of-the-art computational and developmental methods, this project will shed light on a deeply important learning problem for children: who they are, and what they can do.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Learning about the self is critical for children's development. For decades, it was believed that young children are unable to conceive of themselves in terms of abstract qualities or traits. Recent methodological advances, however, have revealed that young children actually have flexible self-representations that include abstract qualities, such as competence. Importantly, children's self-views influence not only their everyday decisions, such as what to do (e.g., which activities to pursue) and what to say (e.g., what to communicate to others), but also their long-term academic outcomes (e.g., standardized test scores) and career pursuit. However, little is known about the cognitive mechanisms underlying humans form self-beliefs (e.g., what are the underlying representations and inferences), as well as how such beliefs impact learning behaviors early in life. Addressing these questions is fundamental to our scientific understanding of the development of self-representations and critical to developing interventions that promote healthy self-representations.

This project aimed to investigate the processes underlying how self-representations are acquired in social contexts, and how such representations guide learning behaviors. We used computational methods to formalize a key aspect of this process: understanding what others think of the self, specifically what biases or prior beliefs others may have against or towards the self. We also employed developmental methods to capture children's actual learning behaviors, specifically challenge selection and persistence, as a function of their self-representations. In short, the major goals of this project were realized through (1) developing and testing computational models of prior social biases, and (2) designing and collecting experimental behavioral data in young children. 

For (1), we proposed that detecting others' biases stems from our ability to think about other people's minds. Specifically, we hypothesized that this process involves considering what evidence about you an observer has access to, what beliefs an unbiased observer ought to form based on that evidence, and how the observer's actual beliefs (as reflected by how they treat you) compare against the hypothetical unbiased beliefs. We built and evaluated a Bayesian computational model that formalizes this process by considering both the evidence that the observer has access to and how they treat the self, as well as two alternative models that lesion each of these variables from the model. We then compared model performance to data collection from online human experiments, and found that the model that considers both evidence and treatment fits human data the best. These findings provide the first evidence for a mentalistic account of social bias inference. 

For (2), we conducted in-person and online behavioral experiments with 4- and 5-year-olds that tested how children integrate information about their performance with social feedback to make learning decisions (e.g., challenge selection, persistence). These experiments manipulated children's performance by developing stimuli for which we could control failures and success (e.g., physical toys that light up, spot-the-difference games). We also manipulated social input: Children were told by an adult who had observed their prior performance that they were either capable of doing an easier or harder version of the task. So far, we found that when children's performance was mediocre, they were more likely to seek out challenges when an adult suggested that they do a harder (vs. easier) version of the task and even persisted longer on a follow-up task. Critically, these results show how adult feedback can guide children's learning decisions, even when children's performance is exactly the same. This work has prompted future directions on whether children are more likely to consider feedback when they are less certain about their abilities.

Collectively, this project led to two key insights. By bridging social-psychological theories about self-inferences with tools in computational cognitive science, we discovered that biases can be inferred via mental state reasoning. Further, while prior developmental work has shown children's sensitivities to observed evidence (e.g., their failures and successes) and others' actions towards them (e.g., others' helping and taking over actions), our work provides initial evidence that children combine these sources of information when learning about the self.

This project resulted in four presentations (one talk, three poster presentations) at conferences, a manuscript under revision at a peer-reviewed journal, and another manuscript in preparation.  In addition, this fellowship provided opportunities to the PI/postdoctoral fellow to receive training in computational models, further develop skills in measuring children's motivation-related behaviors, and work on professional development.
